It's a skinnier bahn mi, but the bread is not too hard on the outside, and not too chewy on the inside.  It's just right.  Pretty good French roll.  I just wish they added more fillings to their sandwiches!  They can be a bit on the paltry side with the meat and the veggies.  I love those pickled veggies!  I always have to ask for extra veggies on the side for my bahn mi, thankfully they've never charged me extra for it.  I also like some hoisin sauce on my bahn mi, luckily we often times take our sandwiches home.    There's also a lot of Vietnamese deli items including various pastries, buns, rolls, and desserts but I always forget about them since all I do is focus on that BIG @$$ bahn mi menu every time I walk in there.  My order is easy, all I do is go, "3 #1, 1 #6, 1 #7, 1 #8, to go, extra veggies on the side please" and I'm done.  So easy, even an old Asian lady can do it!  Dakao takes credit/debit cards but they prefer cash instead.  Service, even if minimal, is always quick and friendly for me.  Hit up Dakao Sandwiches if you want a big bahn mi for a mini-mi price!

Vegas tends to bring out the DRUNKEN GARBAGE DISPOSAL in me, among other things...  Anyone who has stayed in a hotel room with me at Vegas will often find crushed chips on my bed, nacho cheese sauce smeared on the side of the sheets, not to mention overturned take-out boxes scattered around all over the room.   After a Room Service FAIL back in July 2010 at the Palazzo, my friend and I decided we would no longer order room service, no matter how drunk and starving we were.  In December 2010, after getting Chinese foot massages, we decided to pick up some banh mi for some drunken eats later that night. I realize this review is over 2 months late, but I'm at home sick (my punishment for the sins I committed last week at Vegas) so I've decided to catch up on some of my Yelp reviews. As far as details go, I normally take notes on my BB so information integrity is not compromised by my alcohol-induced memory loss.   DAKAO SANDWICHES is located in an Asian Shopping Plaza on Spring Mountain Road in Chinatown (8 min cab ride from the Strip). They offer 10 banh mi varities for $3 each. They also have various Banh Bao (steamed chicken and pork buns), Banh Cuon (steamed rolled noodles), Xio (sticky rice) and Cha Lua (steamed pork sausage) and Mon Trang Mieng (desserts) and a variety of juices and sodas.  I ordered the Combo Banh Mi which was served in a flat French baguette.   CC's accepted with a $8 minimum.  THE MORNING AFTER...  I woke up to breadcrumbs on the pillowcase and trailed along the floor which was no surprise, but as I walked to the front drawer, laid the real SHOCKER... I found chunks of the baguette scattered all over the floor and underneath the drawer. Apparently, when I stumbled back into the hotel at 5 AM (according to my friend), I had broken off pieces of the baguette because the banh mi fixings were scant and the bread was dry.   My more sober friend had the same assessment, she said the banh mi was really bready and dry, there was just 3 slices of meat (ham, headcheese, and bologna) , there was very little mayo and the scant amounts of pickled daikon and carrots just got lost in the bread.  So even operating under auto pilot I STILL knew this was a Banh Mi FAIL!

My mom told me about this place as I was looking for some Vietnamese sandwiches. These are the skinny version but they taste better than majority of the places in town. If you buy 5 sandwiches, you get 1 free. You have the option to leave the veggies in the sandwich or placed outside so it's in a baggy and you can add it in yourself. Their banh cuon dakao is very tasty as well.

In my ongoing struggle to find truly good Vietnamese food in Las Vegas, I finally made it out to the supposed best sandwich shop around. I ordered the Banh Mi Dac Biet (house special) and the Banh Mi Thit Nuong (grilled pork). Both were $3.25.  I ate the Thit Nuong on the night of purchase, and I saved the Dac Biet for later. The latter held up nicely after a quick toast in the oven, which is a pretty standard result.  I won't really go into too much detail on the sandwiches. The components taste nice and seem fresh, but I don't think there's enough meat, pickled veggies, cilantro, or even jalapeno. In other words, it's kinda like Subway but with fewer veggies. The overall result, unfortunately, is that the sandwiches are not very filling, and they leave you with bread as the main after-flavor.  Maybe I'll check out some of the pate chaud or banh bao on the counters if I'm ever in the area again. Otherwise, I'm going to wait for something good from California (and no, Lee's Sandwiches does not count).

I come here every time we visit Vegas. It's not the best I've ever had, but it's the closest I can get to the ones my mom makes at home. Living in Phoenix, there are very few Vietnamese sandwich places to choose from and they're all terrible. Sketchy area. Try to avoid using the restroom here.

I think the fact that they are cheaper than hue thai makes it taste better, the bread is baked every hour which you can taste, but the grilled pork was marinated badly and was thickly cut and oversalty.  Because the meat is essential to the sandwich it is unfortunate that I had to give three stars instead of four stars.  I plan on going back and trying their other sandwiches like the veggie, egg, and the number one cause I heard their pate is good.  We'll see...

Yummy variety of Vietnamese sandwiches with other specialty items such as rolled rice cakes with pork (banh cuon thit) and sticky rice. They even have banh mi with Chinese sausage & egg. Friendly service and they open early for breakfast!!!

First time checking this place out. Definitely will be back. Friendly service with wide variety of food options. I ordered the sardine sandwich and the bf got the pork roll. Idk about you guys but I love sardines and they did not go light. I got a sandwich filled with sardines fresh and pickled veggies. I absolutely recommend. The bread was light and flaky too. Pork roll was also good, he doesn't eat veggies so he ordered double meat, it was a generous amount. They have takehome pork rolls and other delights including some sweets. I recommend the sesame ball filled with mung bean chewy outside with a not too sweet center. Loved it.

I had heard that this palace is the best in Vegas, so I tried it out. There's a place in the valley of l.a. that has really amazing combo banh mi, so I tried the combo sandwich and the BBQ pork from here, along with cafe su da.   Get the BBQ PORK!!!!! It was waaaaaaaay better than Lee's. Really good marinade and pork was delicious. The combo was meh.   I'd hands down choose this place over lee's for my banh mi, but I may hit up lee's for their coffee since they give more and it seems stronger.

Who said that woman cannot live by bread alone!  They have never been to Dakao!  Delicious crispy crust on the outside and oh so tender on the inside!  I ordered the House Special which was amazing.  I love cilantro and jalapeno (ingredients in my favorite margarita)!  My friend ordered the grilled pork.   At 3 bucks, I thought that the sandwiches were going to be tiny.  WRONG!  Perfect size for lunch (with an iced coffee).  Aware of the lack of seating, we took our sandwiches to a nearby park.  We split our sandwiches since I started to eat the wrong one (I was hungry).  Luckily, we were both very happy with each other's choice.  :-) Next visit, I am bringing a group of co-workers so we can sample the menu!

Actually came in for the seseme ball desserts but they were out. Ordered 3 different sandwiches but 2 of the 3 were wrong and the bread was hard..they don't have prices on the desserts and the "nam" (fermented pork and pig skin) so watch for pricing. Was charged 5.50 each for such a small portion.

Great little find from other Yelpers. The owner was very patient as I couldn't decide. It was a good break for my wallet from the Strip Food joints. The grilled pork was really good. So good that we started out with 3 sandwiches and ended up with 6. He let us just buy two more and gave us one free. Great for our plane ride home later. The Cafe Sua Da was really good too. Just the right balance someone and the expresso was not bitter and. It too sweet on the sweetener side. Well worth the find.

Quick/efficient service and banh mi making and also tasty cheap banh mi!   For $3.40 I got the #5 cured pork and rolled pork banh mi. I like that the baguette is longer and narrower, which makes eating a lot easier and less messy. The cured pork was delicious and they did not over do it with with cilantro and jalapeno slices. Apparently their Viet coffee is also very strong as most of the people in my party could only drink 1/3-1/2 of their cups. Highly recommend coming here to pick up a quick lunch.
Just ok.  Not very much meat in #8 grill chicken sandwich.  Ordered 2 iced coffes, but they could only make 1.  I still choose Hue Tai for vietnamese sandwiches.
Ordered the banh cuon here. It was pre made and it was only $6. It was good. They have other stuff here but I was just craving banh cuon.

My family and I ordered 4 sandwiches; 3 special and 1 thit nuong.  I was not impress, the bread was not crispy and fluffy.  It was rather stale and chewy. The expression from my wife and kids said it all when they bit into their sandwiches. Bored and a little disappointed just like the sandwiches.    I also ordered the Nam; which was $6 buck for 10 cubes.  To me that was well worth it.    Still getting a one star since we were very excited before we got there for the sandwiches and left very disappointed.  BTW one table with only 3 chairs.  If you're planning to stay go elsewhere. Better yet I would go elsewhere going forward.

Same good food, slight facility upgrade, more to go offerings. I'm glad this place listens to me. It only took 3 years but my god, it's 3years too long since I've been here. In another 3 years we should be able to get a Michelin Star!
The sandwiches our family ordered were good, we stopped by here to grab togo food on the way home and was pleasant happy with out on the road snacks...

Since vietnamese sandwiches are something I have on a weekly basis at home, I was really craving one during my frequent trips to Las Vegas (I have family here). After looking on yelp for a vietnamese sandwich location in vegas and not finding any listings, my hopes were down.  But then my boyfriend had mentioned that he saw a Dakao location that he had passed.  So, we ventured on to Dakao Sandwiches here in Vegas. When we got there, the inside of the sandwich shop was very plain and didn't have any furniture or anything yet. But this was understandable since they had just opened up and are new.  However, they had a simple menu consisting of 8 different types of Banh Mi (vietnamese sandwiches).  I had the roasted chicken sandwich (my favorite and usual), which was very good. The chicken and ingredients in the sandwich were very fresh and tasty. Also, the sandwich was warm when I got it, so I knew that they had made the entire thing to order.    + pros: very good vietnamese sandwich  + cons: very small location. no space to sit down. pretty much a takeout only. very limited menu. but im sure they will expand once they get going.  great addition for vegas, since there are not many other places that have the Banh Mi sandwiches. hopefully there will be demand!

Horribly disappointed in the Banh Mi Ba Le special.  I used to come here a lot until they went cheap on the sandwich. The meat were sliced so thin you can see through them.  I get pissed off everytime I open my sandwich and all I see is veg and jalapenos. Dakao, I quit you.

The banh mi here isn't even that good. Overrated for sure. The staffs are rude, gave us an attitude for ordering more food. They say buy 5 get 1 free, but the free ones barely had anything in it. We should've just went to Lee's Sandwich. The staffs there are friendly and professional. That's where we went to get drinks after ordering here. We felt unwelcome and rushed.

Dakao is incredibly inexpensive, they have amazingly quick service, and their food is delicious! I spent no more than $5 coming here and was able to get a grilled pork sandwich and a coke. I've been going to the Mr. Sandwich just down the street from here for years when I used to live in Las Vegas, but found out from a friend that they closed. I love getting Vietnamese sandwiches since they're usually quick, easy, and delicious. I was really sad to hear that my usual spot closed down, but I'm super glad I found this place.   Dakao is a great addition to the Spring Mountain neighborhood and you can tell that many of their customers seem like they're regulars. Everyone who walks in here seems to know what they already want and I don't doubt that they consistently deliver great product. The grilled pork sandwich I tried her was amazing and I definitely regret not ordering at least two of them! I can't wait until I'm in town again to try their other sandwiches on their menu.

The banh mi here is good, not great like places in OC. The bread and vegetables are fresh. They load too much meat in the sandwiches, which maybe some people will like, but it really should be a balance to be a great sandwich.

We were on the hunt for a Vietnamese banh mi sandwich to escape the crowd on the strip. For the most part this establishments offers a decent sandwich, however, it does has it flaws.  Cons: - The bread was too flaky and had very little chew - The ingredients were okay, but nothing stood out - Service was a bit slow  Pros: - Friendly service - Decent amount of ingredients in the sandwich  We tried both the cold cut special (dac biet) and the bbq pork (thit nuong).
Buy 5 get 1 free.   Great value. The beef and chicken are really tasty. They do not skimp out on the meat! Consistently great for years!
The meatball sandwich is delicious!  Buy 5 and get 1 free! The pricing is awesome too!!

Let me just tell u ... this place is great.. super yummy and super cheap sanwitches r huge and only 4 bucks tasty good and cheap give it a try ! Its places like thus that make me happy i jumped out of my comfort level...

BS +++  BANH MI SOMETHING NICE!!!! I never had Viet-sammiches and let me tell you.  I much rather have this than an IN-N-OUT and that says a lot.   The sandwiches in this spot are small but for $3.40 ARE YOU SERIOUS? They are long and skinny but the meat ratio is superb.  The veggies are fresh and delectable.  This place as an adorable cashier who's speaks English pretty well so you can ask as many questions as you would like.  I ordered the chicken and the beef.  Both were fresh and soft.  I am going to make sure to order the 5 +1 free special before I go home to NYC.  The wait time is none.  The place is very small.  It only has two tables.  Who cares! Take it to your car.  Go walk it like it's your new fave pet.  Go find a nice bench.  Take a long walk in the park and watch the sunset with it.  Just enjoy it because let me tell you for $3.40 this is the closest you'll get to heaven Banh Mi on Earth.    Location is CLEAN, PROFESSIONAL. ORGANIZED Staff Awesome, friendly, spoke kindly, and was patient. Parking lot is SHARED and SMALL Restrooms Did not see one Seating Very few.  Take it home!  * Boomsauce scale. BW = Dis $@% is BASURA! (Garbage). Not recommended. BS = it's just O.K. (experience) BS+ = Yo! I like this place. BS++= That's Whoa! This place good. BS+++= Dayumm! This place is fkn DOPE!

So it's been a while since my last review but here it goes. I heard a lot of rant about this place and finally during errands I got a chance to stop by. I ordered the #1 Dac Biet House Special. That banh mi packed some serious punch. The meat was soo flavorful. The bread is really yummy and crunchy, skinnier baguettes than normal but longer. The veggies were fresh and those fresh jalapeño slices had a nice kick.   The place looks kinda dingy but please overlook that, the banh mi's are exceptional. There's not really a place to sit so I took mine home. I came late towards the afternoon and they had a limited selection of their other offerings so I was happy to leave with my banh mi and a drink. They have a cooler with a wide selection of drinks. I went for the Tamarind juice which was super good, sweet and sour.   I have to go and eat another banh mi from Mr. Sandwich later this week so I can make up my mind on that last 5-star. These banh mi's were so flavorful though I'm caught in a dilemma.

This is best place for Vietnamese "banh mi and ca phe sua da." The french sytle bread is soft and crunchy.  The line is short and the owner is friendly. If you are in Las Vegas, and you want a Vietnamese sytle sandwich. This is definitely your first choice. My wife and kids love this place.

How can you go wrong with these authentic bahn mi, wife had the veggie - oh to die for, I had the grilled pork then the beef both perfect, I would have liked more jalapeño and should have asked, saw other Vietnamese people order after me - where the locals go for a quick, cheap bahn mi

I'm a fanh!  I ordered the house special banh mi for $3 and I was very satisfied!  I love the price, the immediacy and, of course, the flavor.   I didn't catch their hours, but this place would be great to go to on the way home from a night on the strip.   I'll be coming back!
We stopped in to try the house special banh mi. The bread always looks hard, but it's a little crispy and soft on the inside.  Would come and try other options like the egg and sausage one next time.

There is no better $3 sandwich in Las Vegas. The bank mi is just about the best that I've had. They are thin sandwiches made on a fresh, crunchy baguette with just the right amount of sweet pickled veges and thinly sliced jalapeño. We love the egg and chinese sausage best, but also the steak and chicken are first rate. Call and order ahead if you are in a hurry.  Also, the sweet dessert cups on the counter are wonderful as is the sticky rice flour cake (not too sweet with a hint of coconut).  Cash only.

What a shame.... This place has really good sandwich but talk about service. I'd give their sandwich a 5 star but their service a -1 so a 2 star is pretty generous. Front lady who's probably the owner, on the phone 80% of the time while I was waiting for 6 sandwich. Seriously? Half an hour for 6 sandwich? The 6th free one is NOT worth my time waiting. Been here before and know the service is slow but this is by far the worse!!! Last time and never again!!!!

This place did a good job with their vegan sandwich option. I don't think I've seen a vegan option for bahn mi sandwiches in Hawaii so I'm impressed with Dakao Sandwiches for offering that! The sandwich is packed full of flavor from the seasoned mushrooms and tofu followed with the herbs jalapeño and pickled veggies ! The sandwich is crunchy and soft as well. Very good place would come back

This is my absolute favorite place to grab a Banh Mi sandwich, without a doubt.  The bread is where it starts. It's made fresh into perfection, balancing your sandwich out with the right amount of crunch and softness. Then from whichever of the ten different types of sandwich you choose, you won't be disappointed. The menu option is pretty universal but this place stays true to its tradition by offering the most popular flavors.   They also have assorted Vietnamese delicacies Saran wrapped like any other hole-in-the-wall joint to go along with your sandwich just incase you weren't filled up. Stock on on those too while you're at it. The place might look like nothing spectacular from the outside but you're mind will change immensely once you take a bite of their Banh Mi, hands down.

I actually like this place and think that the sandwiches are pretty good. My girlfriends whom I came here with disagree. We all ordered number one, the house special with pate, ham and pork roll. They thought the bread was too hard and the sandwich was too dry.  They also didn't find it all that flavorful.   I however thought it was good.... Maybe my standards are lower?  But I do know my Vietnamese food well.  It could have used a bit more mayo but I thought the vegetables and pate were on point. The bread was a little dry for me but I think it's cause we went at the end of the day. They could have also put a little more meat in the sandwiches but the sandwich itself was pretty big. I finished one for dinner and was full the whole night. The place is really small with no seats so it's more of the pickup and to go spot.   Other than sandwiches they also sell some coconut desserts. Didn't get to try it but they looked good. They also have a buy five get one free deal.
Dishonest cashier, did not return change!  Food not so great. Not worth the money. Old men hang out playing Chinese chess sort of place

Lunch time and we were craving a sandwich! I remembered reading about Dakao so we gave it a whirl. It's in the corner of an unassuming tiny strip mall. You hardly notice it driving by. I tried the vegetarian option, my boyfriend, the beef  - it was quite interesting.  For those of you that are offended by strong flavors then its not for you.   We thoroughly enjoyed our lunch, left satisfied and it didn't break the bank. It is a no frills, simply put, Vietnamese take on hoagies. Nicely toasted french bread with a nice selection of fillings.  Must have the coconut jello too, the look does not do it justice!  It was yummy!!

If you're looking for a good banh mi shop on Spring Mtn...go here! Don't stop at Lee's, keep driving lol. It's my first time here, but I'm impressed with the cheerful, fast service and good prices. I got the #6 grilled pork banh mi. I opened my sandwich to check out the goods and it's a skinnier sandwich than what I'm used to, but the meat ratio was good. I wish it had more veggies! The bread was fresh, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Next time, I'll try the other sandwiches. They do offer other small appetizer/snack like items. There is limited seating. Your best bet is to take your food to go. They offer a special buy 5, get one free for the beef sandwiches!

It doesn't look like much from the outside... Actually, it doesn't look like much from the inside either. But this poorly decorated, seemingly run-down little shop is home to my 'Holy Grail' banh-mi.  There's no seating; unless you count the rickety plastic patio furniture out front. There's a single table and 2 chairs. Don't expect to claim it yourself. Its usually taken by patrons of the nail salon next door or little old Vietnamese grandpas.   The meat tastes better here. The veggies fresher. And the bread softer and more delicious than any other banh mi bread I've ever had. As much as I'd prefer to stop at Dakao, I find it an epic struggle to make it during business hours. They close at 8pm during the week and 6pm on the weekends. I generally don't work at 9-5 schedule so I consider those hours a little limited for me. Regardless, when I come I'll order a variety of edibles  and can't forget a refreshing Vietnamese Iced Coffee. If available, I'll stock up on the rolled noodles with pork, sesame balls, and any other good-looking sides they have available.  There's also deli case filled with things I cannot actually identify. In my years of patronage, I've never asked nor purchased anything from said case. There are meat looking items and jellied things in there that I've found a little intimidating and downright unappetizing. I suspect the contents to be more popular with the authentic Vietnamese customer.  And like many Asian owned establishments on Spring Mt -- cash Only.

My mom lives in San Jose, CA where there are dozens banh mi places clustered together, battling it out for banh mi supremacy. Well, actually, they are just battling it out for survival since the competition is so fierce.  We only had two banh mi's here (the grilled pork and house special), but the two sandwiches right up there with the ones from San Jose. The baguette could have been a bit crunchier on the outside, but other than that, these were delicious. The meats were grilled just right, the vegetables were pickled just right, and the friendly man at the counter offered to put any of the condiments on the side (jalapeno, cilantro, etc.).   I think they did something with the mayo sauce that gave the sandwiches a little extra flavor boost, but I couldn't be sure. Anyway, if you have a craving for banh mi and don't feel like flying down to San Jose, drop by.

Solid 4 star...due to price and taste!  This place is a true hole in the wall...inside the corner of a mini mall on Spring Mtn, in the same parking lot as Pho Saigon 8 and BBQ King!  Starting off with price and value, this place is awesome. The sandwiches are about $3, and they are filled with plenty of goodies and yummy meats. The sandwiches are fairly large, and one banh mi should fill a normal person up, maybe with a drink and something else on the side. I made the mistake of ordering two since they are inexpensive, and almost ate both because they were so good!  Pic : http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dakao-sandwiches-las-vegas?select=31yJvfSRysdpLR-XyYTwfw#31yJvfSRysdpLR-XyYTwfw  I heard the bread here is made fresh every 45min....It was very good,with a slightly crispy/crunchy outside but soft and tasty on the inside.  I tried the #6 Banh Mi Thit Nuong (Grilled Pork) and #12 Banh Mi Bo Nuong (Beef Steak) with a Thai Tea in the bottle! I think I preferred the taste of the beef here vs the pork, but the Pork sandwich had all the good veggies and a bit more flavor overall in the sandwich! The thai tea was good and cheap at a little over a dollar a bottle!  Closeup on Beef : http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dakao-sandwiches-las-vegas?select=Y6Uvy-r9B-uNLl6zJYt3Mg#Y6Uvy-r9B-uNLl6zJYt3Mg  Closeup on Pork : http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dakao-sandwiches-las-vegas?select=CnVprCR56D32cy2w5DN72g#CnVprCR56D32cy2w5DN72g  Only a tiny table with three chairs to eat...so this place is a to-go kinda shop.  I can definitely see myself ordering a bunch of sandwiches here for a party!  I think this whole meal including the drink ran me around $7-8, so definitely check it out for some cheap eats!

Anyone that tells you that Lees sandwich is the best bahn mi GTFOH!! this is where vietnamese people and real bahn mi eaters go to get their bahn mi. their bread is unlike anyone and their flavors are awesome. i've tried the bbq pork i believe #6  the #1 and #2 those are my favorites.  Also they offer stuff in this place like a big variety of asian drinks and stuff like bahn guan,bahn bao, siopao, which are also really good. another thing i see when people eat here is they always seem to order their  iced vietnamese coffee. I've had it but its super strong for me but if you like strong coffee this is what you want.  Overall when i'm in the mood for bahn mi this is thee go to place.. everyone else is WHACK!

$3.00 Vietnamese sandwiches that are smaller than your usual but the bread is crunchy and the fillings are fresh.  I like the shredded pork, the combo, and most choices except for the grilled/charbroiled pork as the meat was dry on that one.  If you buy 5, you get one free!    What is kind of funny is that I grabbed a $.99 Arizona tea can and they charged me $1.50.  I asked about that and she just shrugged.  Oh well.  By the way, be sure to eat it within a short time of buying to enjoy the crunch of the bread or else you must toast it for optimal flavor.

I was craving some vietnamese sandwiches and found this place on yelp. Saw 4 stars and thought it must be a really good place to try. I tried their house combination and grilled chicken. They use baguette bread instead of the other kind of bread I was used to. To be honest, my review is solely based on my experiences from my home town. The baguette bread was too crispy and they were pretty skimpy on their filling. The flavor wasn't too great on the house special. I love the house special (#12 and huong lan in sac). I was hoping to get that same taste. But the meat and pate just didnt taste right. The grilled chicken was pretty tasty though. I just wish there was more of the pickled carrots and softer bread.

I'm not really a fan of Vietnamese sandwiches because of the ingredients, so it has to be a good sandwich for me to give it 5 stars.  Came here for lunch on a Saturday. I ordered the pork sandwich - I always order that grilled pork whenever I go to a Viet restaurant. The sandwich was about 10 inches (?) and packed with flavor. This is not a saucy sandwich so you don't have worry about a mess.   Delicious sandwich, cheap and filling!  Dakao is my go-to restaurant for a "dry" sandwich. (My moist sandwich go-to place is Capriotti's..check out my review for that place!)

Here's the skinny... these are skinny banh mi. But as long as the skinny is filled with tasty morsels, I'm all in!  I consider Dakao my favorite banh mi go to, but it isn't without its blemishes. I always get the vegetarian tofu option, but I should qualify this by letting you know that 2 times out of 5 they are out of this option! Not cool. When they do have it, it is the real deal because they have a special, flavorful tofu filling. I am not exactly sure what's in there, but it tastes like super savory onions and soy sauce and... good things.   The store is super small, and we never want to sit down and eat the sandwich there. It just feels a little odd, so we end up eating in our car, and then our car smells like the wonderful, but odorous veggie filling. I am not really a fan of my car smelling like food. (We're the type of people that put doggie bags in the trunk.)  Plus, we've never been successful in using our credit card, but based on the other reviews, it can be done. Either way, I hate having to beg to use plastic.  Still, despite the blemishes, the vegetarian filling here is the star for mi.

Got a banh bao and it was cold and dry. They could have at least heated it back up. Towards my last couple bites, I bit into something hard. Which is fairly unusual for banh bao. It looked like a piece had broken off of someone's tooth.

I recently stopped by the Bahn Mi (Vietnamese poboy) shop by my work for lunch again and decided it was time to pen a review on this place.  When I walked in, all the other customers were speaking Vietnamese, which is par for the course at this place. I ordered two poboys so that I can take one home for supper: the #1 House Special and the #6 Marinated Pork. I rarely mention exact prices in a review, but the House Special, pictured on top, was $3.40 and the Marinated Pork was ten cents more. The most expensive poboy at this shop is $4.00, and if you buy five of them, you get one free. The shop is primarily for carry out, but they do have a couple tables where you can eat. This option may appeal to you if you're really hungry, or if you're an artistic type that likes to hang out at dives and order a black coffees at a gas stations.  The House Special (#1) is delicious. Its protein is three types of thinly sliced Vietnamese deli meats which I am wholly unqualified to identify. The Marinated Pork (#6) was equally delicious and is my recommendation for those with a less adventurous pallet.  Both poboys were dressed with a slight amount of mayonnaise, fresh jalapenos, julienned carrots, cucumber, and what I believe to be shredded sweetly pickled radish. None of those things individually sound particularly appealing to me, but the combination is in fact on point. They come with cilantro as well, but because my genes make cilantro taste like dish soap, I had them hold that. My poboys were just spicy enough to contribute harmoniously to the flavor complexity of the poboys without burning my mouth in the least. That being said, the shop uses fresh jalapenos, which, by their nature have a lot of variance, so don't blame me if your poboy turns out spicier than a drunk drag queen at a quinceniera. I've had that happen too in past. The best part of the poboys is the thin baguettes they come on, which I believe are baked on site. In any case, plenty of people come here just to buy their baguettes. I have also tried their sardine poboy and their pork roll (sausage) poboy, both of which I also recommend. The shop sells various Vietnamese baked goods and desserts, and their cold bento box is particularly popular with the Vietnamese clientele. I tried it once, but my Western pallet just wasn't suited for many of those novel flavors. The Thai coconut juice is something I wouldn't get again, but the shop has a decent selection of Asian cold drinks to choose from.  Dakao Sandwiches is a gem, if not a hidden gem, right in the middle of Chinatown, and it is definitely worth the trip.
Banh mi is good...just wish that there will be more meat. Banh uot is good. Services are great. Will come back again.

*Real rating is 3.5, but rounded up due to how friendly the counter guy was and the fact that they made my sandwich in about 45 seconds.  I walked in looking for BBQ pork, but the guy suggested I try roasted pork (off the menu item?). It was pretty tasty. Bread was great, meat was good, veggies good, etc.   I do prefer the banh mi place near UNLV that starts with a P (too lazy to look up the name), but this one was very good as well. I think I prefer the spread a little bit better at the other place.   Stupid thing I have to note... they have no diet drinks.. at all. Tons of full calorie, but no diet. I know this is just me being a calorie crazed freak so this fact in no way impacts their rating.. just making a note for others that prefer diet soft drinks.

This place is fantastic. Their coffee is pretty friggen strong so prepare yourself if you order one! Their sandwiches are amazing, and I can vouch for their #1 (House Special) and #12 (Beef Steak). You can tell the bread is fresh because it's just so soft and melts right in your mouth. Their pate is so delicious, they spread it on their House Special Sandwich, adding more flavor. They offer a lot of interesting foods from sweet rice to sesame balls, to  prepared meats and veggies. Now I want another sandwich...

Pt 1: My first time here. I got the house special for my dad, the bread was crunchy and looked yummy. And my dad enjoyed it. I will definitely be back.          2/5/2016 pt 2: This is the second time they gave me the shitty bread! The reason why I go there is for their fresh baked baguette I didn't know until I got home. I mean everybody else before me got the baguette, so I didn't think anything of it. How rude of them! I go there at least 3 times a week. Grrrrrrr I took off 2 stars for the store bought bread they pulled on me again

Small little shop next to Sunfood market. It's in the same plaza as Pho Saigon 8 and BBQ King.   Probably my favorite place in town to get a Bahn Mi -- though there aren't many good choices in Las Vegas. It's quick and very easy. I usually get the House Special ($3.25)... it's pretty much a combo of the ham, meat, pate, veggies, etc.   The sandwiches are actually a bit on the thin side. There probably isn't enough meat or veggies inside but the total flavor is still decent. It'd be great if they gave more meat in the sandwiches but their bread is amazing. They make it fresh daily so it's never rock hard like some places.   Would recommend orders to go. It's a really tiny space so there aren't that many tables in there for you to eat.

All of the Vietnamese sandwich shops that my family went to when I was young have long closed, or sold off to people who let their quality decline. So my mom and I ventured to try this place next to her hairdresser after the owner suggested this place. The young cashier speaks Vietnamese and English, so you do not need to fear the language barrier. I saw many people of all different ethnicity enter and order without issues. They are also patient enough if you are like me and get into fights with your family about who gets to pay.   There is one table inside the restaurant and two outside. This place is more of a take out venue for a quick grab and go lunch. Although it does not provide places to lounge about, it offers a wide range of excellent Vietnamese options. We ordered five special sandwiches, one meat stuffed bun, a plate of ground pork and mushroom rolled noodles, and a plate of red pork bites. The sandwiches were everything a good banh mi should be; crunchy, savory, sweet, complex, with a bite from the green peppers. The noodles are a favorite since childhood and I recommend getting some Vietnamese sausage to go with them. The steamed meat bun, after reheating, is the perfect breakfast with a cup of strong coffee.

This is most definitely our family's favorite place for Vietnamese Poboys. Quick and easy. I always call ahead 15 minutes and I usually order 12 sandwiches. They have a buy 5 get one free deal. I pay for 10 and get two free. The special is a great go-to sandwich but I LOOOOVE the grilled pork.

Price update. Sandwiches are now $3.25  they went up .25 Very peculiar experience today at Dakao. Ordered a veggie sandwich and was told not available but all other sandwiches have the same veggies.  Place is still dirty and has a peculiar smell. not from baking bread either

if you know what you want, call and order ahead, cause the place is small! they have good cheap banh mi, buy 5 get the 6th free. good fresh desserts too! beside banh mi, i love their banh cuon (steamed rice roll with mince meat), so yummy!!!

Bread itself is good but texture of the nem nuong was soggy and spam like. It was definitely not what it should be. We asked for veggies to be on the side and they put it all in the sandwich anyway.  What made matters worst was the guy at register charged over 15% tax on 2 sandwiches. The sandwiches are $3.25 each. Total came out to $7.50 according to the cashier. We ask him why the extra dollar charge. He said it was tax. There were people waiting behind us so we didn't want to gripe over $1 but it's the principle. Not coming back to this place again and wouldn't recommend it to anyone either.
This place have refrigerated dessert only.  Coffee is too bitter. The place is dark and only one person working. Sandwich ia not tasty enough.
I ordered the grilled chicken sandwich. Not what I expected. Chicken was dry, I was anticipating a BBQ chicken favor. I probably won't go back.

Sandwich was good! My friend bought me a sandwich from this place. So good I came back for more!!! Order a chicken sandwich! There's a .50 cent charge if you use s credit card. Buy 5 sandwich get 1 fit free!!! There's really no seating area. So order and go!

Dakao is banh mi heaven.  So far, I've tried the #1, the vegetarian, and the #6 bbq pork.  The bread is FANTASTIC, the service is friendly and super fast, and the price is awesome.  BBQ pork is my favorite, followed closely by the #1 house special.  Vegetarian is not bad by any stretch, I just wasn't a fan of the texture (tofu, mushrooms, and some kind of slaw?). Sooooo happy I found this place!

Sadly, the only place in town for decent Banh Mi.  Bread is decent, fillings are ok, butter and pate are below average.  But put them all together, the bread save the sandwich.  This place would not make a top ten list if compared to orange county banh mi.  For Vegas, it's decent.  Here is my tip for ordering at this place.  Get the cold cuts, ask for extra meat ($1), you can actually mix the meats you want.  If you don't, you will not get a decent and substantial sandwich.  If you wanna go crazy, cuz sometimes, we want more, get the extra meat, and ask for extra egg.  Now, this might be too much for one person to finish, eat half and save the other half for later.

I've eaten a lot of banh mi in Vegas, which has a lot of choices, and never felt strongly enough to rate any of them. But I'm happy to give the thumbs up to the #10 at Dakao. This place is a real hole in the wall. Just grab your sandwich and go, nothing to see inside, but the #10 is great: scrambled egg and sausage, with the usual yummy veggies. This one I will be going back to, unlike the others I've tried. The only drawback is that they don't serve those fruity slushies.

Sandwiches are the best in town as far as i know.  The staff are fast and pleasant, not fast and rude or fast and mean and scary like some cashiers tend to be in the Vegas Valley.  I must warn you, the shop is very difficult to find as it isn't clearly labelled as a banh mi ba le or even "sandwich shop" on any of the plaza signage.  It is nestled in to the right side of Annie's Hair & Nails in such a way that if you blink or get something in your eyes, it is invisible and you have to call Captain Kirk for resources.  JK.  I love these po boys at this cute little shop! Reminds me of back in the day in L.A. or LA-  both!!
They have quite good banh mi but their service was sux, 15 mins waiting for 3 special sandwiches and they gave the girls who ordered after us the banh mi first WTH?

They don't have much of a selection here but the sandwiches are really affordable and good.  They bake their bread everyday, and you can buy just the baguette.  I think they put jalapeno in their sandwiches so if you can't handle spicy you should let them know.  I like their grilled pork and the pork skin sandwich, I also like to get their Vietnamese iced coffee and a young coconut.
Friendly Sandwich shop. Try the BBQ pork or beef Sandwiches. Buy 5 get 1 free. you'll like their "A" HEALTH RATING!
Pretty good bahn mi, but they are kind of skimpy with the veggies. Make sure you ask for more! The grilled pork and grilled steak sandwiches are both pretty tasty.

Mostly, if you're going to a banh mi store, you'd stick with the banh mi.  However, the banh uot here are quite good.  Made like my mother used to make at home.  The only shortfall of that dish is the weak nuoc mam.  But I think that must be due to them altering for the western palate.  The banh bao had a nice skin (moist), but it lacked solid flavor.  The sardine sandwich I got was the best part of the meal.  Should be eaten immediately though, since the sauce causes the bread to go mushy.

I don't have Vietnamese sandwiches that often but suddenly had a craving for it. Found this place on Yelp decided to give this a try. I got the #1  House Special which is $3.75, and got a noodle dish that's on the shelf and a fresh made pork roll for a total of $16. The sandwich is a bang for your buck for at footlong you can't beat the price. It's very flavorful, can't wait to try their other sandwiches next time. The only complain I have is the parking in that plaza is horrible. I was lucky to find a spot there at lunchtime otherwise I will have to park on the side streets.

In my opinion, I prefer Dakao Sandwiches over Lee Sandwiches for the following reasons:  + shorter wait (Lee's Sandwiches can take up to 30 minutes in line plus waiting for the food - I never understood why. It's not fairly cheap and great tasting.)  + tastes better (I usually order a combo sandwich and the meat in this sandwich tastes so much better at Dakao).  + they sell other various vietnamese meats and foods as well. It's the fresh kind of stuff and not the packaged things.  + buy 5, get one FREE!

Good but not great.  $3.50 for a sandwich and buy 5 get 1 free is an awesome deal.  I ordered the #1 classic banh mi.  It was a good sandwich but nothing IU would go out of my way for.  Meat was tasty but the bread seemed s limp and needed to be toasted.  It lacked the light crispy and flakiness of a classic baguette for banh mi.

I was here maybe a week ago and the guy that worked at the front is nice but I don't really like the way they do their line system. I Order my food and when it was time to get my drink he told me I could go to the refrigerator and pick a drink as I walked over there and grab a bottle water and came back five other people were being taken care of and here I am waiting in line again for him to finish all these five people before checking me out. I've already waited in line before I ordered and now I have to wait again because I went to go get a drink. They need to improve on that and not have to make someone wait all over again just because they went to go grab a bottle water. Also when I ordered my sandwich with sunny side up eggs and Chinese sausage sandwiches he said it was extra for sunny side up eggs and extra for sausage which was fine I have no problem with that. But when I receive the sandwiches it was missing sausages and when I told the guy at the front about it but I guess since it wasn't the original guy that checked me out the guy told me that they normally don't put sausages with the Sunny Side eggs. I know that and I paid extra just to have the sausages put in there so I would like to be able to have my sausages which I ordered. Overall they were nice about it and I did like the banh cuon there.  I will come back again and hopefully they will improve this time.

One of the best Vietnamese sandwiches that I've ever had other than my moms. I ordered the buy 5 get 1 free and I'm so glad I did.   I just ordered the black eyed pea sweet rice with coconut milk was heaven.  It is a delicious sweet dessert pudding similar to rice pudding but 10X better.   Just tasted the bbq beef one and WOW was it good. I think the bread makes it for me. The outside is crusty yet the inside is airy and very light. The meat with grilled onions is very tasty almost like a Vietnamese grilled cheesesteak without the cheese and a whole lot better than some of the best cheesesteaks I've had. The pickled daikon & carrots are sweet with a little tang and the cucumber, jalapeño. & cilantro gives the sandwich a FRESH taste that leaves your mouth filled with a refreshing yet very tasty palate. If you share half like I did with your significant other you're gonna wish you hadn't.   The Dac Biet sandwich has the pate, steamed pork meat, and homemade ham with all the goodies they put in with all their sandwiches.  Meat was skimpy and if you overload it, it wouldn't be as good.  It was just the right amount to have a tasty yet fresh taste.  I have yet to taste the other 4 sandwiches but I'm sure they'll delight me as we'll as the 1st one.   Dakao makes their own bread which is fantastic and the woman who makes it in the back wears a mask which I approve. The strip mall is not that clean but the pleasant woman (speaks very broken English) who takes your order and the delicious sandwiches & snacks makes you forget the uncleanliness.  I look forward to duplicating their homemade mayo and sandwiches.  It will be difficult because it is very hard to find great french bread that doesn't feel like a rock.
Delicious! Stopped in here on a whim and the sandwiches are amazing. Crispy bread and perfectly grilled meats. Yes and yes!

They are very proud of their bread here, which is advertised as a new batch every 45 minutes (as I recall... anyhow, baked fresh throughout the day). If bread is the main thing about a bahn mi to you, you will be happy. It explodes in a shower of crumbs and after I ate my two sandwiches sitting on the floor at the airport the rug looked like it had snowed.  But if you're into fillings as I am, you'll be disappointed. They are pretty meager. I had the #1 dac biet and #7 pork and pork skin and both were very very slim on the meat and sauces and not much more generous with the vegetables. I also asked for it "extra spicy" and my sandwiches barely registered on the Scoville scale.  Net net, I'm giving it a 4 rather than a 3 (my true score) because the bread really is special, and the price can't be beat.

This is a very unassuming little shop. I have had them bookmarked for some time, but finally got the chance to pick up a little something for lunch.   I tried the BBQ pork banh mi. They take credit Visa and Mastercard with a minimum $8 purchase. They advertise that their bread is baked fresh every 45 minutes and you can tell. It's crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. The sandwich is quite large as well, compared to some of the other banh mi places I've been to, the prices are really great as well. Just $3 for every sandwich on their menu.   Definitely a great deal, I'll be coming back again soon to get my banh mi fix on.

Stopped by here for a quick lunch before a haircut a couple of days ago. I was pretty excited to see that they don't only have banh mi, but they also have banh cuon, xoi, nem chua, and other Vietnamese specialties for takeout as well. We ordered 2 banh mi dac biet (the house special sandwich) and a couple of trays of banh cuon.  The bread for the banh mi was really good - crispy but soft. The sandwich overall tasted fresh and well-balanced, not too salty. You do get more bang for your buck at Lee's (more meat), but I preferred the more authentic flavors and better balance of meat / veggies / bread here.   The banh cuon seemed fresh when I bought it, but since I bought it to go and ate it for dinner later that day after putting it in the refrigerator and reheating it, I couldn't really tell you. It wasn't bad by the time I got to it.   Just a heads up, there isn't really anywhere to sit and eat. We ended up going to Greenland market down the street and sitting in their foodcourt to chow down.   It seemed like a lot of people called in their orders and just came in to pick up their food - seemed like regulars, too. The man working the cash register wasn't rude, but he was pretty unfriendly (not surprising, I'm used to that), but it just wasn't 4-star service. In this day and age of yelp, service is paramount and the food wasn't SO good as to be able to stand on its own.   Next time I'm in Chinatown, I'm definitely going to stop by here to stock up on this taste of home.
